result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI Cause Injury (2+) and PAC Cause Injury (2+). The defendant was found guilty of OWI Cause Injury (2+) and the other charge, PAC Cause Injury (2+) was dismissed by the court.

  • Justin F Anderson was found guilty of OWI Cause Injury (2+), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(2)(a)1.
  • Justin F Anderson was found guilty of OWI Cause Injury (2+), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(2)(a)1.
  • Justin F Anderson was found guilty of OWI (3rd), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.descr: Notice and acknowledge of def voting ineligibility

records.addlTxt:
[Clerk: MK]
case called at 11:19am. 
Defendant Justin F Anderson in court with Attorney David P. Geraghty.  ADA Jeffrey Shock appears for the State of Wisconsin.  
Maximum penalties recited; Constitutional rights given; plea of " No Contest " entered on Counts #1, #3, #5; factual basis stipulated; victim rights compliance verified (the victim impact statement and restitution information is submitted; the victims are not present); the Court accepts the pleas, finds Mr. Anderson guilty, and orders Judgment of Conviction entered.

On Motion of the State, the Court reads-in and dismisses Counts #2,#4,#6.

On Counts #1, #3 and #5 each, the Court withholds sentence, and places Mr. Anderson on Probation for three years, with conditions:
--on Count #5 only: to serve 75 days in the Jefferson County Jail, with work-release privileges for all purposes, to commence forthwith; the Court clarifies that good-time applies to this jail term
---Mr. Anderson is required to report for commencement and service of jail term with absolute sobriety and without non-prescribed controlled substances in his system; non-compliance will result in loss of work-release privileges without further process.
--to maintain absolute sobriety: no consumption of alcohol
--no presence in bars, taverns, liquor stores, with the exception for employment at Roundys; Mr. Anderson may work within the liquor department of the store to the extent that it is appropriate for employment purposes 
--no operation of a motor vehicle without a valid drivers license
--to undergo any assessment, treatment, and counseling as deemed appropriate by the Agent
--to undergo random alcohol or drug testing as required by the Agent 
--the Court holds restitution open for sixty days; a hearing will be scheduled on this 
--on Counts #1 & #3: to comply with DNA sample provision
--on Count #1: to pay costs of $268 plus $250 DNA surcharge
--on Count #3: to pay costs of $268 plus $250 DNA surcharge
--on Count #5: to pay fine of $1000 plus costs= $1998, plus $200 DNA surcharge
Days credit for time already served:  0 days

The Court orders outright (not as conditions of Probation): 
--Revocation of drivers license for 24 months, on each Count concurrent with each other 
--County alcohol and drug assessment ordered
--to attend a Jefferson Victim impact panel attendance
--Ignition Interlock Device required on any vehicle driven by the Defendant for a 24 month period , on each Count concurrent with each other
--6 demerit points assessed

The Court indicates that if the DNA surcharge is found to be unconstitutional, and the Defendant has not yet paid the surcharge, then the Judgment of Conviction is to be amended to remove the surcharge payment requirement.  If the DNA surcharge has been paid and the ruling that found the DNA surcharge unconstitutional directs the clerks to reimburse the amount paid, then the clerk is to refund the amount paid to the Defendant. If the reimbursement is not mandated, then the amount will be kept.
Felony firearm/voting prohibition warnings give.
Recess 12:00pm.

NEXT:  schedule Restitution Hearing within sixty days, but as far out within that time limit as available
Plea/sentencing hearing on August 29, 2014 at 11:15 am.
